Engineering Research Center for Waste Oil Recovery Technology and Equipment of Ministry of Education Chongqing Technology and Business University Chongqing 400067 PR China ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. γ-Valerolactone (GVL) is considered as a versatile platform chemical obtained from biomass refinery. In this study, eco-friendly group III metal (Sc, Y, La) triflates were examined as homogeneous catalysts for microwave-assisted transfer hydrogenation of ethyl levulinate (EL) to GVL under mild conditions. Experimental results revealed that the selectivity of GVL has a positive relationship with the Lewis acidity of metal ion, which is related to effective charge density of the metal center (3.23, 2.81, 2.60 for Sc3+, Y3+, La3+, respectively). The stronger Lewis acidity of metal ion, the higher catalytic activity of MPV reduction. Among these catalysts, Sc(OTf)3 exhibited the best catalytic activity, achieving 98.4% EL conversion and 92.4% GVL yield at 140 °C in 3.0 h. Furthermore, Sc(OTf)3 showed high stability and recyclability for at least ten reaction cycles. In addition, a plausible reaction pathway and mechanism were proposed. Graphical abstract Sc(OTf)3: An efficient homogeneous catalyst for microwave-assisted transfer hydrogenation of ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone under mild conditions. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Transfer hydrogenation Ethyl levulinate γ-valerolactone Sc(OTf)3 Microwave heating 1 Introduction The development and utilization of renewable resources such as biomass, solar energy, geothermal energy, hydropower, wind energy, ocean energy is extremely urgent in the context of carbon neutrality [1–3]. Among these sustainable routes, biomass refinery is considered as a green and promising technique due to its carbon cycle pathways in nature. Hence, biofuel and platform chemicals (e.g. furfural, 5 - hydroxymethylfurfural, lactic acid and levulinic acid, etc) obtained from biomass transformation achieve increasing attention in the last decades [4–7]. Among these, γ-valerolactone (GVL), originated from cellulose and hemicellulose, is identified as a key compound for its widely application such as a green additive in lubricant, plasticizer and fuel and green solvent in organic synthesis and biomass refinery [8–11]. Currently, levulinic acid and its ester are considered as important bridge molecules connecting biomass and GVL. Hence, efficient conversion levulinic acid or its esters to GVL attracts increasing attention. Typically, GVL is obtained by lactonization of 4-hydroxypentanoic acid or alkyl 4-hydroxypentanoates, which is produced through hydrogenation of the carbonyl group upon levulinic acid or its esters. Hence, the catalytic system must have both hydrogenation and cyclization active sites. Two kinds of hydrogenation strategies have been explored based on the hydrogen sources, namely direct hydrogenation using molecular H2 and transfer hydrogenation (CTH) using organic hydrogen donor agents. For the former, various metal catalysts with Au [12–14], Ir [15–17], Pt [18], Ru [19,20], and Ni [21,22] have been applied in this process, but the drawbacks such as hazardous pressurized H2, the over-hydrogenation of substrate and short-term operation limit its application. CTH process employing alcohols or formic acid as the hydrogen source can effectively avoid the above drawbacks and has been widely investigated [23–25]. According to the catalytic mechanism type, CTH can be divided into metal hydride reaction, in-situ H2 formation process and Meerwein-Ponndorf-Verlry (MPV) reduction [23]. And the catalytic system based on MPV reduction attracts most attention due to high thermochemical stability of catalyst, inexpensive, readily available and easily handle of hydrogen donors and high selectivity of target product. The first MPV reaction of carbonyl compounds was independently published in 1925 by Meerwein and Verley [26,27]. After that, heterogeneous catalysts such as hydrous zirconia [28,29], ZrO2 [30–33], MgO [34–36], Zr(Hf)-based zeolite [37–41] and homogeneous catalysts such as aluminium or titanium alkoxides [42–46] were evaluated. Meanwhile, the catalysts consisting basic or acidic sites could also improve the (trans)esterification reaction of organic acid and alcohol, which is beneficial to convert 4-hydroxypentanoic acid or alkyl 4-hydroxypentanoates into GVL. For example, high GVL yield was achieved over amphoteric ZrO2 [33] and Lewis acidic Zr-β [39]. Recently, organic - inorganic hybrid materials such as Zr-MOFs, Zr-Phy, Zr-HBA, Zr-BDB also displayed great activity [47–54]. However, relatively harsh operating conditions (Table S1) are always required. Recently, microwave heating is considered as an efficient and green technology to promote processes and modify selectivities compared to traditional heating such as oil bath heating and electrical heating. What is more, some reactions that hardly performed by traditional heating can easily occur under microwave heating [55]. Meanwhile, compared to the heterogeneous catalysts, homogeneous catalysts are widely applied in biomass refinery due to the high process efficiency with the great yield and selectivity of product under the mild conditions [56,57]. However, traditional metal salts such as AlCl3, ZrOCl2, are instable in the presence of water. For example, Tang etal. [58] found that AlCl3·6H2O, SnCl2·2H2O, and ZrOCl2·8H2O were easily hydrolyzed to metal hydroxides in 2-butanol solvent at 240 °C. Conversely, metal triflates such as Er(OTf)3, Sc(OTf)3 exhibit great thermochemical stability in both water and organic mixture. Wang's group reported that Er(OTf)3 showed excellent catalytic activity for the production of lactic acid from cellulose, giving 89.6% yield of lactic acid at 240 °C in 30 min. This outstanding catalyst was used to five cycles without obvious deactivity [59]. Inspired by these findings, herein we attempt to employ group III metal (Sc, Y, La) triflates as the catalysts for converting levulinate esters to GVL with microwave-assisted heating under mild conditions. The effect of reaction parameters was studied in detail, and a plausible reaction pathway and mechanism were proposed. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials ML (98%), EL (98%), BL (99%), GVL (98%) 2-propanol (99%) and 2-butanol (98%) were provided by J & K Technology Co. Ltd. (Beijing, China). Sc(OTf)3 (99%), Y(OTf)3 (99%), La(OTf)3 (99%), ZrO2 (98%) and Zr(OH)4 (97%) were obtained from Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd. (Shanghai, China). All other chemicals were supplied by Chongqing Chuandong Chemical (Group) Co. Ltd. (Chongqing, China) and used without further purification. 2.2 Comparative study on microwave-assisted catalytic transfer hydrogenation CTH of EL to GVL Batch reactions were carried out in a UWave-2000 multifunctional microwave reaction/extraction apparatus (Shanghai Sineo Microwave Chemistry Technology Co., Ltd, China) equipped with a 100 mL sealed Teflon reaction vessel and an automated system of frequency control to prevent over-heating. In a typical test, 2.0 mmol EL, 10 mL 2-propanol and 0.1 mmol Sc(OTf)3 were loaded into the vessel and then sealed. Then, the designed reaction temperature was achieved within 5.0 min and kept at a certain reaction time, followed by cooling down to room temperature. 2.3 Sample analysis Qualitative analysis of samples based on the mass spectrometric data was performed on a Shimadzu GCMS-QP2020 apparatus with a SH-Rxi-5Sil MS column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm). Quantitative analysis of samples based on the peak area was carried on a Shimadzu GC-2010 Plus instrument equipped with a flame ionization detector and a RTX®-5 column (30 m × 0.25 mm × 0.25 μm) using naphthalene as the internal standard compound. The EL conversion and GVL yield were calculated according to Eqs. (1) and (2), respectively. (1) EL conversion ( % ) = 100 − Unreacted EL mole Initial EL mole × 100 % (2) GVL yield ( % ) = GVL mole Initial EL mole × 100 % 2.4 Recovery and reuse of Sc(OTf)3 After reaction, the reaction mixture was transfer into a 50 mL eggplant-shaped flask and then the reactor was washed carefully with 2-propanol (1.0 mL × 3). Then, the recovered Sc(OTf)3 powder was carefully obtained by a rotary evaporator (RV 3 V, IKA, China) at 90 °C under -0.01 MPa. Finally, fresh 2-propanol (1.0 mL × 3) was used for transferring the recovered Sc(OTf)3 into the reactor for recycling test. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of various catalysts Comparative study of various catalysts on microwave-assisted CTH of EL to GVL was carried out and summarized in Table 1 . As shown, only 2.6% EL conversion with 2.4% isopropyl levulinate (i-PL) yield was achieved without any catalyst, suggesting that the thermochemical reaction can be ignored under selected reaction conditions (Table 1, entry 1). When 0.1 mmol Sc(OTf)3 was added, up to 62.0% EL conversion and 48.9% GVL yield were obtained, which was also obviously better than traditional oil heating (Table 1, entries 2 and 3). This could be explained that Sc(OTf)3 has a good microwave conductivity caused by the strong polarity of anions, which could significantly promote both internal and in-core volumetric heating through coupling effect between microwave energy and raw molecules [60]. Several by-products including i-PL, isopropyl 4-hydroxypentanoate (i-P4HP) and isopropyl 4-isopropoxypentanoate (i-P4(i-P)PA) were also detected by GC-MS (Fig. S2). For Y(OTf)3 and La(OTf)3, the yield of GVL was decreased to 12.2% and 1.3%, respectively (Table 1, entries 4 and 5). The selectivity of GVL has a positive relationship with the effective charge density (ECD) of the metal center (3.23, 2.81, 2.60 for Sc3+, Y3+, La3+, respectively), which is calculated by a ratio of between atomic polarizability tensor charges and effective ionic radii of the metal center [61]. The metal ion featuring higher ECD value exhibits stronger Lewis acidity, which is benefit for the formation of a cyclic six-membered transition state among 2-propanol, EL and catalyst based on traditional MPV reduction mechanism. This finding is also well according with previous studies, where Zr-containing catalyst exhibited superior catalytic activity of MPV reduction than that of Sn-containing catalyst [41]. Meanwhile, we also found that all catalysts except La(OTf)3 can be completely dissolved in 2-propanol, which further explained the lowest EL conversion in the presence of La(OTf)3. Considering that metal triflates can partly hydrolyze into HOTf with a trace of water in the reaction system [62]. A control experiment using HOTf as the catalyst was conducted (Table 1, entry 6). But only 34.4% i-PL was achieved, indicating Sc(OTf)3 was the real catalyst. Finally, traditional catalysts such as ZrO2 and Zr(OH)4 were hardly fulfilled the preparation of GVL under test conditions (Table 1, entries 7 and 8). The above findings conclusively demonstrate that homogeneous Sc(OTf)3 acts as an effective and stable catalyst for microwave-assisted CTH of EL to GVL. 3.2 Effect of reaction temperature and time The effects of reaction temperature and time on the microwave-assisted CTH of EL to GVL were investigated in the range of 110 ∼ 140 °C and 1.0 ∼ 6.0 h, respectively. The results depicted in Fig. 1 suggest that this efficient catalytic process was highly temperature-dependent. When the reaction temperature changed from 110 to 140 °C for 1.0 h, the EL conversion and GVL yield progressively increased from 47.6% and 33.9% to 80.2% and 69.9%, respectively. Nevertheless, the yield of main by-product, i-PL, decreased with the temperature increased. This could be attributed to the fact that higher temperature benefits for the CTH of i-PL to GVL and this was well matched with the distribution of i-P4HP and i-P4(i-P)PA. EL conversion and GVL exhibited a gradual increase trend when the reaction time prolonged from 1.0 to 6.0 h in all tested temperature range. For example, when reaction time changed from 1.0 h to 6.0 h at 120 °C, the EL conversion and GVL yield increased from 61.9% and 48.9% to 96.9% and 86.5%, respectively. But, obvious difference for i-PL and i-P4HP were displayed. For i-PL, an increasing trend was observed at 110 °C and an opposite trend was exhibited in the range from 120 to 140 °C, indicating that higher temperature benefits the conversion of i-PL due to high steric hindrance of isopropyl group upon i-PL. Meanwhile, high steric hindrance of isopropyl group also resulted in the stable presence of i-P4HP, which was further converted to GVL and partly to i-P4(i-P)PA. Thus, 140 °C and 3.0 h are required to achieve excellent process efficiency. 3.3 Effect of Sc(OTf)3 dosage The effect of Sc(OTf)3 dosage on the microwave-assisted CTH of EL to GVL was studied at 140 °C up to 3.0 h. As exhibited in Fig. 2 , EL conversion and GVL yield increased with the Sc(OTf)3 dosage changed from 0.05 mmol to 0.1 mmol. For example, 73.1% EL conversion and 63.1% GVL yield were achieved when 0.05 mmol catalyst was loaded, where the values increased to 98.4% and 92.4%, respectively with the addition of 0.1 mmol Sc(OTf)3. Meanwhile, the i-PL yield reached the maximum value (8.9%) at 0.75 mmol Sc(OTf)3 and then remarkably decreased to trace at 1.0 mmol Sc(OTf)3, indicating that transesterification and hydrogenation of EL simultaneously occurred in this process. The product distribution demonstrated that the CTH of EL was faster than its transesterification reaction. Further increasing Sc(OTf)3 amount to 0.125 mmol, a slight increase of GVL yield was observed. From perspective of the process economics, 0.1 mmol Sc(OTf)3 would be the best choice in this process. 3.4 Effect of various hydrogen donors It has been considered that the type of hydrogen donor plays a key role on the CTH process. Hence, the catalytic activities of several alcohols such as methanol, ethanol, n-propanol, 2-propanol, n-butanol and 2-butanol was investigated in detail under the optimized reaction conditions. The results in Fig. 3 showed that, secondary alcohols exhibited more excellent catalytic performance than that of primary alcohols. For example, 31.1% EL conversion and 30.9% GVL yield were achieved using ethanol as the hydrogen donor. Conversely, both the EL conversion and GVL yield increased substantially in secondary alcohols. 98.4% and 100% EL conversion and 92.4% and 94.7% GVL were obtained for 2-propanol and 2-butanol, respectively. Accordingly, the hydroxyl group of alcohol was oxidized to resulting carbonyl or aldehyde group based on MPV reduction. Hence, the process efficiency of GVL production relies on the reduction potential of employed hydrogen donor, which is obtained from the difference between the standard molar enthalpy of formation for the alcohol and carbonyl compound. The GVL yield increased as follows: 2-butanol ≈ 2-propanol > ethanol > n-butanol ≈ n-propanol > methanol, which is generally consistent with the change trend of reduction potential of hydrogen donor (2-butanol (69.3 KJ/mol) < 2-propanol (70.0 KJ/mol) < n-butanol (79.7 KJ/mol) < ethanol (85.4 KJ/mol) < n-propanol (87.3 KJ/mol) < methanol (130.2 KJ/mol)) [63]. The slight difference could be attributed to the steric effect of the solvent, which is more evident in the secondary alcohols. 2-Propanol was selected to the optimized hydrogen donor due to its lower price than that of 2-butanol (80 and 165 RMB per 1.0 L for 2-propanol and 2-butanol, respectively (J & K Technology Co. Ltd.)). 3.5 Effects of various substrates The routes of various levulinate ester such as methyl levulinate (ML), EL, i-PL and butyl levulinate (BL) were explored for high value-added utilization of biomass. So, it is necessary to investigate the suitability of this efficient process for GVL production from different substrates. Fig. 4 displayed that this catalytic strategy exhibited outstanding universality for different levulinate esters. For example, 100% ML conversion and 82.2% GVL yield were obtained when employing ML as the substrate. However, better catalytic activities were achieved with EL and BL, respectively. This phenomenon can be explained by lowest steric effect of ML compared to EL and BL, which is benefit for i-PL formation through transesterification reaction between ML and 2-propanol. Besides, only 63.7% GVL yield was achieved when using i-PL as the substrate, indicating the steric effect of isopropyl group is unfavorable for the formation of GVL. 3.6 Cycle test of Sc(OTf)3 The recyclability of Sc(OTf)3 is a key parameter for potential industrial application. Hence, the cycle tests were conducted at 140 °C up in 1.0 h. As exhibited in Fig. 5 , Sc(OTf)3 can be used at least ten cycles without obvious loss of catalytic activity by simple post-treatment. After ten runs, up to 81.0% EL conversion and 69.9% GVL were still obtained. This is much better than traditional Zr-based solid catalysts, where obvious activity loss was observed due to the carbon residues upon the surface of catalysts. 3.7 Reaction pathway Based on the product distribution and effects of various parameters, we proposed a probable reaction pathway for microwave-assisted CTH of EL to GVL (Scheme 1 ). Firstly, the carbonyl group upon EL was selectively reduced to ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate, which is further converted to GVL by intramolecular transesterification reaction. Meanwhile, intermolecular transesterification between EL and 2-propanol results in the formation of i-PL, which also can be converted to GVL through similar cascade reactions proposed for first route (Second route). According to the results of reaction parameters, the total yield of the i-PL and its derivatives is less than 25%, indicating the first route is the major way for GVL production. Besides, different rate-determining steps were observed based on the product distribution for these two routes. Ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate was not detected by GC-MS in the first route, revealing that the step of EL hydrogenation limited the whole process efficiency. Conversely, the presence of i-P4HP and i-P4(i-P)PA confirmed that the intramolecular transesterification of i-P4HP was the reaction-limited step in the second way. Based on the above elaboration and previous reports [41,47,49], a probable transformation mechanism for transfer hydrogenation EL to GVL was also proposed and displayed in Scheme 2 . Initially, 2-propanol was activated by unsaturated Sc3+-O2− pairs on Sc(OTf)3 (A), giving complex intermediate (B). Then, electron rich oxygen of carbonyl group upon EL coordinated with electron deficient H atom upon hydroxyl of 2-propanol to yield a cyclic six-membered transition state (C). Meanwhile, hydrogen transfer (C) was achieved among the cyclic six-membered transition state, giving coordinated ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate and acetone with Sc(OTf)3 (D). Next, the regenerated active site of Sc(OTf)3 (A) is released of ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate (F) and acetone (E). Finally, GVL (G) was obtained by intramolecular transesterification of ethyl 4-hydroxypentanoate (F). As shown in Scheme 2, the interaction among the carbonyl group, hydroxyl group and metal ion is the key factor for the formation of the cyclic six-membered transition state (C). The stronger interaction among the carbonyl group, hydroxyl group and metal ion, the higher activity of MPV reduction of carbonyl group. Hence, Sc(OTf)3, featuring the strongest Lewis acidity, exhibited the best performance for CTH of EL to GVL. 4 Conclusions In summary, we present an efficient strategy for GVL production by microwave-assisted CTH of EL to GVL under mild conditions using Sc(OTf)3 and 2-propanol as the homogeneous catalyst and hydrogen donor, respectively. The catalytic activity strongly relies on the appropriate Lewis acid strength of metal ion and resulting counterion coordinating ability. At 140 °C and 3.0 h, 98.4% EL conversion and 92.4% GVL yield were obtained. In addition, Sc(OTf)3 can be used at least ten cycles without obvious loss of catalytic activity. Finally, a suggested reaction net was also proposed. Hence, we believe that this catalytic system provides an efficient method for GVL production and has great potential for application in biomass refinery. coredata.dc:description: γ-Valerolactone (GVL) is considered as a versatile platform chemical obtained from biomass refinery. In this study, eco-friendly group III metal (Sc, Y, La) triflates were examined as homogeneous catalysts for microwave-assisted transfer hydrogenation of ethyl levulinate (EL) to GVL under mild conditions. Experimental results revealed that the selectivity of GVL has a positive relationship with the Lewis acidity of metal ion, which is related to effective charge density of the metal center (3.23, 2.81, 2.60 for Sc3+, Y3+, La3+, respectively). The stronger Lewis acidity of metal ion, the higher catalytic activity of MPV reduction. Among these catalysts, Sc(OTf)3 exhibited the best catalytic activity, achieving 98.4% EL conversion and 92.4% GVL yield at 140 °C in 3.0 h. Furthermore, Sc(OTf)3 showed high stability and recyclability for at least ten reaction cycles. In addition, a plausible reaction pathway and mechanism were proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Sc(OTf)3: An efficient homogeneous catalyst for microwave-assisted transfer hydrogenation of ethyl levulinate to γ-valerolactone under mild conditions
